column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Transurban has been involved in the Reconciliation Action Plan (RAP) program since 2014, recognising and embracing the contribution Australian businesses and employers can make to Australia's reconciliation journey. In FY23, Transurban launched its third Innovate RAP, which will be in place until 2025. Areas Transurban is focusing on for this period include delivering an employment strategy, broadening involvement in its RAP internally and delivering a cultural learning strategy.
column20: Reconciliation Action Plan, reconciliation journey, cultural learning strategy

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: This year, Transurban continued its partnership with Multicap (disability employment and skills-development service) and Q-Free Australia (Transurban's image processing and tolling service provider), with Multicap participants joining the Q-Free team cross-checking vehicles without tags on Transurban's Brisbane roads. Multicap participants review Q-Free's licence plate identification outcomes for quality assurance. This initiative enables people with disabilities to gain skills, training and employment experience in a technology-based industry.
column20: Multicap, Q-Free, licence plate identification

column6: Operations with significant actual and potential negative impacts on local communities
column13: In Queensland, Transurban was invited to participate with other industry leaders in the Queensland Road Safety Round Table hosted by Queensland Transport Minister Mark Bailey, which identified the importance of upgraded managed motorways, speed compliance, driver education and awareness.
column20: Queensland Road Safety Round Table, speed compliance, industry leader

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: This year, Transurban continued to advocate with the government for more flexible project delivery models with the potential to ease labour constraints. For example, Transurban's Employment White Paper submitted to the Federal Government called for solutions that will support its delivery partners, including structuring projects better to support the participation of lower-tier design and construction companies.
column20: Employment White Paper, labour constraint, government

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: Transurban screens suppliers with financial, Director, and company ultimate beneficial ownership checks to identify any known issues related to labour concerns, illegal behaviour or indicators that may lead to adverse human rights impacts, including insolvency risks.
column20: Supplier screening, labour concern, human rights impact

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: The Sustainable Procurement Risk Heat Map is available to Transurban's employees to map the category of goods or services they want to purchase against the assessed risk level. It allows employees in advance to seek internal advice to incorporate into contracts or to investigate measures before engaging in work.
column20: Sustainable Procurement Risk Heat Map, risk level, internal advice

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: The Tender Response Schedules are used during larger procurement activities, usually over a certain threshold in contract value. As noted in previous statements, these schedules require businesses to answer questions and provide evidence demonstrating the respondent meets Transurban's codes and policies, aligning with the UNGPs and core questions that provide information on how they mitigate the risks to people in their operations and extended supply chains.
column20: Tender Response Schedules, larger procurement activity, supply chain

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: Transurban's contractual controls provide binding obligations for suppliers to meet labour-related and modern slavery clauses, including reporting potential or actual cases to Transurban and attesting to passing on payments to contractors down the supply chain, helping to reduce the risk of labour-related issues beyond Tier 1.
column20: Contractual control, binding obligation, modern slavery clause

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: Transurban's new supplier high-risk triage is used when a new supplier is added to the Transurban system to determine if they are providing high-risk goods or services. This request is directly routed to the Sustainable Procurement Manager to investigate high-risk procurement activity. This action may lead to desktop reviews or engagement with employees or suppliers for further information on the procurement activity and the controls in place.
column20: New supplier high-risk triage, high-risk good, Sustainable Procurement Manager

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column8: Credit card and purchase order reviews
column13: Transurban conducted credit card and purchase order reviews on its suppliers at intervals throughout the year. Purchase orders and credit card spending for higher risk categories identified in Transurban's risk heat map are reviewed. These include spend with suppliers who have existing contracts, Master Services agreements or are on preferred panels.
column20: Credit card and purchase order review, risk heat map, supplier

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: The supplier evaluation tool is a new addition to Transurban's suite of tools and is in the process of being fully implemented. During the reporting period, this tool was developed internally to capture information from the risk heat map, tender response schedules, publicly available information, and information provided through Transurban's supplier engagement. This tool will provide an ongoing assessment of suppliers and how they mitigate the risks of modern slavery in their operations and supply chains.
column20: Supplier evaluation tool, risk heat map, modern slavery

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: In FY23, Transurban piloted a digital risk screening tool to review adverse media, sanctions, watchlists and ownership structures. Transurban reviewed information concerning 44 suppliers across major projects, construction, technology and professional services. No information was discovered that increased the assessment of risks from Transurban's risk heat map.
column20: Digital risk screening tool, adverse media, information review

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: Contractors for all major projects have and implement procedures to record and manage community complaints. Transurban's independent external whistleblowing service is available for anyone, including employees, customers and members of its supply chain, to raise issues related to fraud, conflicts of interest, bribery, corruption and modern slavery.
column20: External whistleblowing service, community complaint, fraud

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: During FY22, Transurban employed a new Sustainable Procurement Manager, who provided Transurban with the opportunity to review processes and actions completed to date and provided advice on future direction in how Transurban assesses and addresses the risks of modern slavery across its operations and supply chains.
column20: Sustainable Procurement Manager, modern slavery, supply chain

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: The Transurban Procurement team is responsible for the operational management of the Sustainable Procurement Program, which leads the priority of work associated with how Transurban and its owned and controlled entities assess and address the risks of modern slavery.
column20: Sustainable Procurement Program, Procurement team, modern slavery

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: Transurban formalised the Sustainable Procurement Business Leadership Group in 2022. It held two meetings in FY22, where the Sustainable Procurement Manager updated members on emerging risks and legislative changes. Members agreed on the roadmap of actions, reviewed and provided input into integrating the sourcing toolkit and the Supply Chain Modern Slavery Grievance Mechanisms and Remediation Guidelines.
column20: Sustainable Procurement Business Leadership Group, Sustainable Procurement Manager, modern slavery

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column8: Supply Chain Modern Slavery Grievance Mechanisms and Remediation Guidelines
column13: The Supply Chain Modern Slavery Grievance Mechanisms and Remediation Guidelines provide information to employees on how to raise an issue relating to actual or potential modern slavery issues in Transurban's supply chain and outline the process for an issue to be triaged, assessed, and what actions may be taken to provide remediation.
column20: Supply Chain Modern Slavery Grievance Mechanisms and Remediation Guidelines, modern slavery issue, remediation

column6: Political contributions
column13: Transurban's Political Contributions Policy prohibits it from directly donating to political parties. However, it does allow participation in public policy dialogues and events on issues that may impact Transurban's business.
column20: Political Contributions Policy, political party, public policy dialogue

column6: Assessment of the health and safety impacts of product and service categories
column13: The safety performance of Transurban roads is independently assessed. Monash University Accident Research Centre has found Transurban's Australian roads to be at least twice as safe as like roads. The International Road Assessment Program (iRAP) rates Transurban's Australian roads at 100% three stars and 91% four stars for travel, and USA roads at 100% at three stars and 63% at four stars for travel.
column20: Safety Performance, Accident Research Centre, International Road Assessment Program

column6: Assessment of the health and safety impacts of product and service categories
column13: In FY22, Transurban launched road incident notification functionality for its Linkt app. It was customers' most-requested service, asked for by 67% of surveyed customers. Since its March 2022 launch, around 164,000 Linkt app users have enabled the live incident notification feature. Between July 2022 and June 2023, Transurban issued, on average, around 656,000 notifications a month Ã¢ÂÂ making it easier for customers to choose whether to travel with Transurban or not.
column20: Road incident notification, Linkt app, live incident

column6: Assessment of the health and safety impacts of product and service categories
column13: Transurban invested in new technology to reduce congestion and improve travel times in the Burnley Tunnel in Melbourne. The tunnel is steep and deep, and motorists tend to slow for the uphill climb to the tunnel exit, creating congestion. Transurban's pacemaker lights give motorists visual cues to help them maintain speed as they climb. The lights operate dynamically in response to live traffic conditions Ã¢ÂÂ when tunnel traffic speeds drop, the lights move faster, encouraging drivers to reach a safe, consistent speed.
column20: Pacemaker light, a live traffic condition, reducing congestion

column6: Assessment of the health and safety impacts of product and service categories
column13: Transurban established a major incident evaluation team to assess serious road crashes. The team uses enhanced analytics to understand crash risk trends and factors and identify and implement road safety improvements. The team also reviewed data on wrong-way driving during lane reversal and Transurban's incident response.
column20: Major incident evaluation team, road crash, crash risk trend

column6: Assessment of the health and safety impacts of product and service categories
column13: Transurban and Neuroscience Research Australia (NeuRA) have signed a new three-year partnership to deliver critical road safety research into occupant injury prevention. This year, NeuRA's research, delivered with Transurban's support, resulted in revised guidelines and standards for child restraints and guidelines for health practitioners when recommending comfort accessories to (mostly) older drivers who use comfort accessories, like seat cushions or backrests.
column20: NeuRA, road safety research, injury prevention

column6: Incidents of non-compliance concerning the health and safety impacts of products and services
column7: Transurban had no cases of non-compliance concerning product health and safety in FY23.

column6: Requirements for product and service information and labeling
column13: Transurban provided access to the Linkt Assist program for customers experiencing financial difficulties. Linkt Assist 360 and the One Stop One Story Hub offer additional support. These services are supported by Transurban's Hardship Policy, in which its Customer teams receive training.
column20: Linkt Assist program, financial difficulty, One Stop One Story Hub

column6: Incidents of non-compliance concerning product and service information and labeling
column7: Transurban had no cases of non-compliance concerning product labelling in FY23.

column6: Incidents of non-compliance concerning marketing communications
column7: Transurban has received two complaints from the Australian Communication and Media Authority (ACMA) but has not received any fines or warnings for non-compliance in FY23.

column6: Substantiated complaints concerning breaches of customer privacy and losses of customer data
column13: In April 2023, Transurban launched the Help Us Stop SMS Scams campaign to incentivise toll-road scam reporting while also educating and empowering customers to act. Everyone who reported an eligible text scam during the campaign period could win an electric vehicle (EV).
column20: Help Us Stop SMS Scams, toll-road scam reporting, EV
